bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John W. Hart, November 10, 1944

div1.p: Hench is delighted that Hart is interested in the yellow fever story and the discovery of Camp Lazear. He discusses his meeting with Ramos and the Cuban government's support to commemorate the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John W. Hart, November 10, 1944
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
10 November, 1944
Doctor John W. Hart
Winthrop Products, Inc.
350 Hudson Street
New York 14, New York
My dear Doctor Hart:
div1.p:
I am interested indeed to hear of your new position, with
its increased possibilities. I am sure you must be enjoying it.

I am delighted that you have maintained your interest in
the Yellow Fever story and the discovery of Camp Lazear. I, too, was
concerned, lest the recent hurricane damaged the building, and I am
writing to Mr. Moran to see what, if anything, has happened.

A curious meeting occurred last week in New York, where I
was attending the convention of the Association of Military Surgeons.
At a reception, I recognized a tall white haired figure as Doctor
Ramos, until recently, Secretary of War of Cuba in the Batista Govern-
ment. It was he with whom I had so many pleasant, but argumentative,
discussions, before he would accept my findings. I have not seen him
for four years; therefore, I did not expect him to recognize me. He
was one of the distinguished guests and was talking to a couple of
Admirals. I sneaked up quietly, touched him on the shoulder and said,
“Doctor Ramos, you may not remember me; I am Doctor Hench, whom .......”
He wheeled around and embraced me in Latin fashion, roared, and said,
“Doctor Hench, you think I don't remember you; how can I ever forget
you? You have come to me from heaven; I was about to fly out to Hot
Springs to see you. How wonderful to see you here!” He had two or
three most interesting propositions to make, and the result was that
he and my wife and I dined together and spent the whole next morning
going over his plans. He has indorsed completely my little plan for
memorializing the little camp and building, and he wants the Cuban
people and Government to participate. There is a lot more to it that
I don't have time to go into at this moment. Needless to say, any con-
sideration that you would care to give will be most appreciated at the
appropriate time.

I will be very glad indeed to receive a half dozen
copies of the article in Horizontes Medicos, and will be especially
anxious to see your own article on the subject. If I can help you in
anyway, please let me know.

I was very glad to receive the half dozen copies of the
Penicillin booklets. They will be most helpful.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service
